content: The crypto and Web3 company located in Nigeria announced on Twitter that it is shutting down:https://twitter.com/njokuScript/status/1646531643371585546?t=XMULGkOrX7GpvSpfa2r5Sg&s=19If you have money on your Lazerpay account, withdraw it via crypto or bank before the deadline.

According to their official statement by the CEO, the reason for their shotting down is the inability to raise funds to kickstart the project.

Na mismanagement make the company dey close so abi wetin?According to what I have read from some sources, it is written that the lead investor in the funding round had withdrawn due to market conditions and disagreements on terms.Quote from: https://brandspurng.com/2023/04/18/seplat-energy-dragged-to-court-as-lazerpay-shuts-down-over-criminal-charges/#:~:text=Nigerian%20crypto%20payment%20startup%2C%20Lazerpay,conditions%20and%20disagreements%20on%20terms.Nigerian crypto payment startup, Lazerpay, shut down last week due to a lack of funds.The shutdown follows Lazerpay’s failed attempt to raise a seed fund last year. comments.author: Wiwo
comments.body: Quote from: SatoPrincess on April 18, 2023, 01:53:13 AMLazerpay nor be crypto exchange, them just dey accept crypto as means of payment for their services. Charles-Tim I watch the interview with Lazerpay founder about two years ago where him dey talk about how much them raise as funds to startup e talk say na over $200k, Wetin happen to the money in such a short time? Na mismanagement make the company dey close so abi wetin? All this tech companies way young people be founder no dey last, them never strong their mind to face challenges of entrepreneurship. I think waiten really be the problem with young startups in Africa and Nigeria in particular na the inability to face market challenges and the lack of prior actions to make their fit fem on the business ground before wanting to live their dream life, some of them a leave lavish lifestyle instead of continually working to improve their platforms to meet current and future demands. For Lazerpay to have started with an initial capital of $200,000 here in Nigeria and the company already folded up after 2 year shows how unprepared and mismanaged the core team have been during this period of their operation in the Nigeria e-commerce sector, for the fact that the company accept cryptocurrency for their services should have been the primary reason why the company should have been more successful even if they're not operating a cryptocurrency exchange. The CEO have a lot of explanation to do and if the proper audit of the company account is done there could be some possible indictment against the company by investors.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: I read the press release I and I could feel the pain in Njoku's words. It hard to build in Nigerian in a place where the government is hostile to crypto development. They Lazerpay tried, they did their best but for any company to move on, the stark reality is that you need funding. Without funding your lofty ideas won't fly. It's been less than two years since they commenced operations. Young CEOs need a lot of "learnings" to do. Well, another crypto company gone but the dream still remains alive - drive crypto adoption in Africa.
